caption_original:
The Little Brown Bat, also known as the Little Brown Myotis, is listed as endangered under the Government of Canada's Species at Risk Act. Once wide-ranging and numerous, populations of these bats have declined steeply in recent years due to habitat loss, human disturbance of colonies, and white-nose syndrome, in which a fungus grows on the bat‚Äôs skin causing death.

Environment and Climate Change Canada is partnering with Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect 178 hectares of wildlife habitat in central Saskatchewan. This area is home to the Little Brown Bat as well as many other species at risk, including the Northern Long-Eared Bat and Canada Warbler. http://ow.ly/XA3P304qWH7
caption_cleaned: The Little Brown Bat, also known as the Little Brown Myotis, is listed as endangered under the Government of Canada's Species at Risk Act. Environment and Climate Change Canada is partnering with Nature Conservancy of Canada to protect hectares of wildlife habitat in central Saskatchewan. This area is home to the Little Brown Bat as well as many other species at risk, including the Northern Long-Eared Bat and Canada Warbler.

August 29 marked the 30th anniversary of the Dr. Neil Trivett Global Atmosphere Watch Observatory, located in Alert, Nunavut. It is more commonly known as the Alert Research Laboratory.

The lab was constructed in 1986 to focus on long-term monitoring of background concentrations of trace gases, aerosols and organic pollutants. It is the most northern permanently inhabited research station in the world and less than 1,000 km from the North Pole. Happy 30th! http://ow.ly/uwon30483PH
